contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox mineral | name = '''Periclase''' | category = [[Oxide minerals]] | boxwidth = | boxbgcolor = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | formula = MgO | strunz = 04.AB.25 | symmetry = Cubic 4/m {{overline|3}} 2/m | unit cell = 4.21 [[Ångstrom|Å]] Z=4 | molweight = | color = Colorless, grayish white, yellow, brownish yellow, green, black | habit = Granular, generally occurs as anhedral to subhedral octahedral crystals in matrix | system = [[Cubic crystal system|Isometric]] - Hexoctahedral | twinning = | cleavage = {001} perfect; {111} imperfect, may exhibit parting on {011} | fracture = Conchoidal | tenacity = Brittle | mohs = 6 | luster = Vitreous | refractive = n = 1.735–1.745 | opticalprop = Isotropic | birefringence = | pleochroism = | streak = White | gravity = 3.56–3.68 (meas.) 3.58 (calc.) | density = | melt = | fusibility = | diagnostic = | solubility = | diaphaneity = Transparent to translucent | other = Fluorescent, long UV=light yellow. | references = <ref name=Handbook>http://rruff.geo.arizona.edu/doclib/hom/periclase.pdf Handbook of Mineralogy</ref><ref name=Webmin>http://webmineral.com/data/Periclase.shtml Webmineral data</ref><ref name=Mindat>http://www.mindat.org/min-3161.html Mindat</ref> }} '''Periclase''' occurs naturally in [[Contact metamorphism|contact]] [[metamorphic rock]]s and is a major component of most basic [[refractory]] bricks. It is a [[Cubic crystal system|cubic]] form of [[magnesium oxide]] ([[magnesium|Mg]][[oxygen|O]]). It was first described in 1840 and named from the Greek περικλάω (to break around) in allusion to its cleavage. The [[Type locality (geology)|type locality]] is [[Monte Somma]], Somma-[[Vesuvius]] Complex, [[Naples Province]], [[Campania]], [[Italy]].<ref name=Mindat/> The old term for the mineral is ''magnesia''. Stones from the [[Magnesia on the Maeander|Magnesia]] region in ancient [[Anatolia]] contained both magnesium oxide and hydrated [[magnesium carbonate]] as well as [[iron oxide]]s (such as [[magnetite]]). Thus these stones, called ''Stones from Magnesia'' in antiquity, with their unusual ''magnetic'' properties were the reason the terms ''[[magnet]]'' and ''[[magnetism]]'' were coined. Periclase is usually found in [[marble]] produced by [[metamorphism]] of [[Dolomite|dolomitic]] [[limestones]]. It readily alters to [[brucite]] under near surface conditions.<ref name=Mindat/> In addition to its type locality, it is reported from [[Predazzo]], [[Tyrol (state)|Tyrol]], [[Austria]]; [[Carlingford, County Louth]], Ireland; [[Broadford, Skye]] and the island of [[Muck, Scotland|Muck]], Scotland; [[León (province)|León]], Spain; the Bellerberg volcano, [[Eifel]] district, Germany; [[Nordmark Hundred|Nordmark]] and [[Långban]], [[Varmland]], [[Sweden]]; and [[Kopeysk]], southern [[Ural Mountains]], Russia. In the USA it occurs at the Crestmore quarry, [[Riverside County, California]]; [[Tombstone]], [[Cochise County, Arizona]]; [[Gabbs]] district, [[Nye County, Nevada]]. In [[Canada]], it occurs at [[Oka, Quebec|Oka]], [[Quebec]] and in [[Australia]], west of [[Cowell, South Australia|Cowell]], [[Eyre Peninsula]], [[South Australia]].<ref name=Handbook/> ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Magnesium minerals]] [[Category:Oxide minerals]] [[Category:Cubic minerals]]
